column4: What document viewer is commonly used to view a document of  MIME type 'application/docbook+xml'?
Any xml viewer will do it
At a guess /usr/lib/* is not in your $PATH, try echo $PATH to find out
In my Ubuntu 9.04 computer $PATH does not include /usr/lib/ . Is it against the rules that an executable has been stored in /usr/lib/ ?
well that is why which could not find it then... what rules are you speaking of?
The $PATH variable has been invented to find executables. But it does not find this particular executable. So one could suspect that this executable is wrongly stored.
I don't have any answers, sorry. I am not experienced in where Gnome puts their executables, maybe try #gnome for more info.
#gnome is not available in this network. And ##gnome is a lame duck.
apparently (according to Google) Gimpnet is the go for #gnome
Yes. Thank you for your help.
no worries, not that I was much :)
Do not denigrate yourself: The discussion was useful for me.
no worries mate, I am more of a tech kinda bloke in the general systems of UNIX, rather than gui's. I am glad you found it useful ;)

It was useful indeed. I had forgotten what I once learned: What is $PATH for. But I am not certain if the File Hierarchy Standard applies here. --  So I appreciate that you helped me a bit along my way.
I am not sure either, another one is Ubuntu meant to conform to the POSIX standard?

My impression is that Ubuntu is not so eager to cling to the POSIX standard. Ubuntu's main targets are others. For example I dare to say that Debian is more eager to cling to the POSIX standard than Ubuntu, and OpenBSD even more so. --  No, not all programs in the Ubuntu repositories conform to POSIX.
just reading on the wiki about FHS, it all started with RedHat, Dell and HP, I think Ubuntu loosely follows it (or is that Debian?)
